original_statement: About three weeks ago my best friend gets kicked out of her house along with her child and she came to me for help. I gladly accepted her and her child to stay at my home rent free until she is ready to go on. My bestfriend and her husband had a huge falling out. I felt extremely guilty. I allowed her to stay at my house for three weeks now. All she has done for me is take and take from me without ever giving. I figured that she was hurt and not in a good place, so I allowed it. After day in and day out of her not cleaning after herself or her son, not helping around the house, and not being a decent roommate is where I feel like I could have done something.

She's been staying with me for these weeks, and all I've seen is her taking advantage of my kindness without offering anything in return. She supposedly needed healing time, so I put up with it. But dealing with her daily mess, her not helping around the house, and their overall inconsiderate behavior made me question if I could have handled things differently from the start.

original_statement: Two weeks ago, we buried my mother in law. It was a sad day that day. My father had a few tears. My mother had a few more tears. My brothers and sisters all gave me a hug. I gave a speech about her life. She was an accountant. She always went to work with a smile. She always got the job done. She was the best accountant at the company. She had a few kids and a husband. They all loved her. She loved to eat cupcakes. She loved them if they had some sprinkles on them. We celebrated this by having a giant batch of cupcakes made for the burial. We all grabbed a cupcake and threw them into the grave before she was buried.
para_statement: It's been two weeks since we laid my mother-in-law to rest, a day filled with sorrow. My father's eyes welled up, and my mother shed even more tears. My siblings embraced me warmly. I delivered a speech honoring her life, noting her career as an accountant. Her dedication and cheerful demeanor made her the best at her company. She was deeply cherished by her children and husband. Her fondness for cupcakes, especially those adorned with sprinkles, was well known. In her memory, we prepared a large batch of cupcakes for the burial. Each of us took a cupcake and gently placed them into the grave before the burial, a sweet tribute to someone so loved.

My siblings wrapped me in warm embraces. I gave a heartfelt speech about her fulfilling career as an accountant, where she always wore a cheerful smile and excelled as the best in her company. Her family adored her, and she was known for her love of cupcakes, particularly those with sprinkles. To commemorate her, we crafted a batch of cupcakes for the burial. Each of us placed a cupcake into the grave as a tender tribute to someone who brought sweetness into our lives.
